various projects

PoliticsD3

Visualizing Congress voting data on various bills using D3.js

website code

My first attempt at D3.js using data from the sunlight foundation api. Currently it is not pretty, but works. The looks will be coming soon.

Every bill has several stages of voting. Clicking on each will move the little legislators to where they voted on the bill. This allows you to see each voting stage and the various ways it breaks down in the various 'Yeas' and 'Nays'. You can see the splits by:

  • political party (red/blue/green color)
  • rough age of legislators (circle diameter)
  • states

While the context of each voting is still a mystery, manipulating the data into something visual and interesting was great practice. Still more to do!

Yolp

A restaurant reviewing website (clone of yelp).

website code

Yolp is a faux-site that was created for educational purposes. The idea was to take an existing site that had a lot going on and try to replicate its functionality. This way, I did not have to worry about the design aspects and could concentrate on functionality and essentially practice programming in a bigger sandbox.

I subscribed to CodeClimate to help focus on making my code better. It helped a lot in finding problem areas. And despite the high rating, it still needs more refactoring. I still have some Laws of Demeter violations and some more organization.

So Yolp is a reconstruction of the popular restaurant reviewing website yelp.com. It is filled with lots of fake data including users, businesses, and reviews.

Features include:

  • Database Design

    • Denormalized some data using of Active Record Counter Cache and custom counters using ActiveRecord Callbacks
    • Use of Database Transactions for creating new reviews and businesses

  • Nested Forms

    • AJAX used for user upvoting and complimenting
    • UJS on search page (so you can search with or without JavaScript)

  • Search

    • Basic postgres searching using tsvector and tsquery
    • Elasticsearch searches the text for the top review of each business. includes text highlighting and ranking.

Asteroids

The classic game of asteroids is brought back through the power of Javascript and the HTML5 canvas.

website code

Diet Rails

A reconstruction of Ruby on Rails.

code

Generally, a good way to have a better understanding of something is to take it apart and try to rebuild it. Sure you might end up with some extra parts, not have nearly as much functionality, and will never use it for any practical purposes... but you end up feeling a wee bit smarter.

  • Session Class

    Provides methods to store and set cookies and the authenticity tokens for CSRF.

  • URLHelper Module

    Dynamically creates helper methods to generate urls.

  • Router Class

    Handles nested routes and sets up regular expressions to match against urls.

  • Params Class

    Stores passed parameters.

  • HTMLHelper Module

    Convenience methods for creating links and buttons.

  • Flash Class

    Provides access to a hash that can be set on one page and retrieved on the next.

  • BaseController Class

    Provides various render, redirect, flash and interfaces with instances of the other classes. It uses the ERB class along with Ruby's binding class to generate rendered content. The binding allows access to all of of methods and variables of the controller instance to be used in the ERB rendering.

Movies and Stars

An original movie-trivia game made for mobile devices.

website

The idea is to place actors and movies into puzzle, so that actors only connect to movies that they appeared in.

I did all of the front-end coding along with the graphics. The game was developed using CoronaSDK.

Poker

Poker developed for the Terminal using Ruby and TDD.

code

The game supports up to 4 players.

Rounds of betting continue until all players have folded, or matched bets.

The program can determine the highest value of a particular hand, give the name of it (like "Royal Flush" or "Two Pair") and calculates a numerical value for the hand, so it can break ties.

Maze Escape

Find the shortest path through a maze.

code

This code uses the A* algorithm to determine the shortest path. The A* algorithm was a good approach because it allows the program to explore all movement options, while giving the more promising moves more priority. Also, doing it this way, the first path that is found will be one of the shortest paths, so the search can immediately end.

The most important bits for this algorithm were:

  • The Manhattan value of each move. Manhattan values are calculated by adding the total number of steps to reach a ceratin space and a estimate distance to the end.
  • The estimated distance assumes there are no walls, so it is just the direct number of spaces to the end position from the current position.
  • Ignoring the previous position. For determining the next set of possible moves, ignoring the previous position greatly reduces the amount of retreading.

Brain Gems

An original word game made for mobile devices.

website

A combination of a crossword and a word jumble, with the shape of the puzzle being a diamond. Each word in the puzzle has a clue and each neighboring answer share letters in common.

I did all of the front-end coding along with the graphics. The game was developed using CoronaSDK.

Queens

Set up 8 queens on a chessboard so that none of them check each other.

code

This classic problem was interesting to solve recursively. Each recursive iteration needed to have several individual branches to explore all of the possibilities. Currently the code stops once it finds the first solution.

Knight Moves

Determine the least number of moves required to move a knight to another position on a chess board.

code

Uses a custom binary search tree class I wrote to determine the correct sequence of moves.

Binary Tree

An exercise into building a Custom Tree Node class for Tree Search searching using recursion.

code

Like a binary tree, but here you can specify the number of children for each node (so it doesn't have to be 2). This can be used for Breadth-First-Search (BFS) and Depth-First-Search (DFS).

code

Includes checkmating, castling, en passant and custom error messages.
